information:
According to public statements, François Villeroy de Galhau, a member of the European Central Bank (ECB) council, indicated there is room for gradual interest rate reductions as inflation approaches the central bank's 2% target. The ECB has implemented seven interest rate cuts since mid-2024, lowering the benchmark deposit rate to 2.25% as of its April 2025 meeting. ECB President Christine Lagarde has noted that future policy decisions will be data-dependent, citing 'unprecedented uncertainty'. A report from Qatar National Bank (QNB) stated that the ECB is expected to continue its interest rate cutting cycle in 2025, driven by a weak economic outlook for the Euro Area and stabilized inflation.

Official data from Eurostat showed the euro area annual inflation rate was 2.2% in March 2025, down from 2.3% in February. The primary contributors to the March inflation rate were services (+1.56 percentage points), followed by food, alcohol & tobacco (+0.57 pp), and non-energy industrial goods (+0.16 pp). Energy prices had a negative contribution (-0.10 pp). According to news reports citing polls from Bloomberg and Reuters, the consensus among economists for the April 2025 inflation figure is 2.1%. A quarterly Survey of Professional Forecasters by the ECB indicated that inflation for 2025 is expected to be 2.2%, with a forecast of 2.0% for 2026.

Recent economic indicators point to a weak economic outlook for the Eurozone. Real GDP growth forecasts for 2025 have been subject to downward revisions. For ten consecutive months, the composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), which tracks business activity, has remained below or near the 50-point threshold separating contraction from expansion. The ECB's Wage Tracker Index indicates a rapid deceleration in wage increases from the peak observed in late 2024. This trend is expected to reduce price pressures in the labor-intensive services sector. Other disinflationary drivers include easing food inflation and a negative year-on-year contribution from energy prices.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: Approximately 4-7 days. Eurostat typically releases preliminary monthly inflation data in the first week of the following month, so the April 2025 inflation rate should be published in early May 2025.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: No. The March 2025 inflation rate was exactly 2.2%, and the consensus forecast from economists (Bloomberg and Reuters polls) is 2.1% for April 2025, which would be at or below the 2.2% threshold.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Inflation continues its downward trajectory or remains flat at 2.2%. The April reading comes in at 2.1% as per consensus expectations, driven by continued disinflationary pressures from weak economic growth, decelerating wage increases, easing food inflation, and negative energy price contributions. This aligns with the ECB's expectations and the broader trend of moderating price pressures.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Inflation unexpectedly increases above 2.2% in April due to month-to-month volatility. Possible drivers could include an unexpected spike in services inflation (the largest component at +1.56pp in March), energy price volatility reversing the negative contribution, or food price increases. Statistical base effects or measurement timing could also push the reading slightly higher than consensus expectations.
forecast.rationale: The evidence strongly points toward a No outcome. March 2025 inflation was 2.2% (exactly at the threshold), representing a decline from 2.3% in February, indicating a clear downward trend. The consensus forecast of 2.1% for April is below the threshold and reflects professional economists' expectations based on current data. Multiple structural disinflationary factors support this: the ECB has implemented seven rate cuts bringing rates to 2.25%, weak economic conditions with PMI at or below 50 for ten consecutive months, rapidly decelerating wage growth from late 2024 peaks, easing food inflation, and negative energy price contributions. The ECB's continued rate cuts signal confidence in moderating inflation toward their 2% target. However, I'm not forecasting an extremely low probability because: (1) March was exactly at 2.2%, so we're at the threshold, (2) month-to-month inflation data exhibits normal volatility, (3) consensus forecasts, while generally accurate at short horizons, can be wrong, and (4) energy prices and services inflation can be volatile. For me to revise higher, I would need to see preliminary data leaks suggesting higher readings, unexpected energy price spikes, or evidence of stickier services inflation. For me to revise lower, I would need confirmation of the consensus forecast or early indicators pointing to an even lower reading.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will the Euro Area Inflation Rate be above 2.2% for April 2025?

Question background:
Euro News: [Euro falls as eurozone inflation sees downward revisions in February](https://www.euronews.com/business/2025/03/19/euro-falls-as-eurozone-inflation-sees-downward-revisions-in-february)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if the Eurozone inflation rate for April 2025 is above 2.2% on an annualized basis according to [Trading Economics](https://tradingeconomics.com/euro-area/inflation-cpi).




Your research assistant's report says:
According to public statements, François Villeroy de Galhau, a member of the European Central Bank (ECB) council, indicated there is room for gradual interest rate reductions as inflation approaches the central bank's 2% target. The ECB has implemented seven interest rate cuts since mid-2024, lowering the benchmark deposit rate to 2.25% as of its April 2025 meeting. ECB President Christine Lagarde has noted that future policy decisions will be data-dependent, citing 'unprecedented uncertainty'. A report from Qatar National Bank (QNB) stated that the ECB is expected to continue its interest rate cutting cycle in 2025, driven by a weak economic outlook for the Euro Area and stabilized inflation.

Official data from Eurostat showed the euro area annual inflation rate was 2.2% in March 2025, down from 2.3% in February. The primary contributors to the March inflation rate were services (+1.56 percentage points), followed by food, alcohol & tobacco (+0.57 pp), and non-energy industrial goods (+0.16 pp). Energy prices had a negative contribution (-0.10 pp). According to news reports citing polls from Bloomberg and Reuters, the consensus among economists for the April 2025 inflation figure is 2.1%. A quarterly Survey of Professional Forecasters by the ECB indicated that inflation for 2025 is expected to be 2.2%, with a forecast of 2.0% for 2026.

Recent economic indicators point to a weak economic outlook for the Eurozone. Real GDP growth forecasts for 2025 have been subject to downward revisions. For ten consecutive months, the composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), which tracks business activity, has remained below or near the 50-point threshold separating contraction from expansion. The ECB's Wage Tracker Index indicates a rapid deceleration in wage increases from the peak observed in late 2024. This trend is expected to reduce price pressures in the labor-intensive services sector. Other disinflationary drivers include easing food inflation and a negative year-on-year contribution from energy prices.

Today is 2025-04-28.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
